Award.AwardTitle: Statistical problems in elementary, analytic, and algebraic number theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The theory of numbers is a very active research area in mathematics, with connections across the entire discipline and with wide-reaching consequences for digital security. This proposal principally concerns analytic number theory, which is that aspect of the subject that aims to answer quantitative questions. Examples include: What does a typical integer look like 'statistically', in terms of the number and size of its prime factors? How many primes are there up to a given height? What about primes differing from another prime by 2 (so called twin primes)? This proposal considers a number of questions of this kind, not only for natural numbers but also for other number systems that have proven arithmetically significant (corresponding to number fields and function fields).

Three specific topics are considered: The first concerns splitting statistics of primes in algebraic number fields. Elliott and Linnik--Vinogradov developed a method for bounding the least rational prime with a given splitting type in an abelian extension of Q. With Micah Milinovich, Pollack will investigate extending their ideas to certain nonabelian extensions. The second topic is the theory of arithmetic functions, especially as it connects with probabilistic number theory. One problem to be considered is that of obtaining error bounds in a classical theorem of Erdos and Wintner. Finally, Pollack will continue his studies of the distribution of irreducible polynomials over finite fields, with particular attention paid to problems motivated by rational prime number theory. For instance, Pollack will study special configurations of irreducible polynomials, including analogues of the prime k-tuples conjecture and the Bateman--Horn conjecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While supported by this award, the PI investigated a number of different problems in elementary, analytic, and algebraic number theory/arithmetic geometry. Specific products include more than 40 accepted, peer-reviewed publications, as well as a textbook published by the American Mathematical Society.

Of the many topics studied, there are a few that deserve special emphasis:

  • The author's joint work (with P.L. Clark and others) on statistical questions in arithmetic geometry, and in particular on elliptic curves. Elliptic curves are among the most-studied objects in number theory, with CM elliptic curves being a subclass of particular interest. Among other results, Clark and I establish sharp upper bounds for the size of the torsion subgroup of a CM elliptic curve. We believe this to be one of the first sharp upper bound results for the size of the torsion in a natural family of abelian varieties.
  • Given a prime number p, an old question of Vinogradov asks for the smallest positive prime that is not congruent modulo p to be a perfect square. This problem can be generalized in several ways. For instance, one can replace "is not congruent to" with "is congruent to", or one can look for primes that are congruent to squares mod p, rather than not congruent. In a more abstract vein, one can view primes that are squares mod p as those that split in an appropriate number field, and then ask more generally about the distribution of primes splitting in number fields. The author published several papers on this theme (some joint with Benli or with Ge--Milinovich). Work of the PI highlights certain limits of existing methods for studying such problems, and suggests new methods.
  • The PI published several papers on the value-distribution of arithmetic functions (some joint with N. Lebowitz-Lockard, L. Thompson, and C. Pomerance), including Euler's function counting numbers up to n that are coprime to n, and Oppenheim's function counting the number of unordered factorizations (multiplicative partitions) of n. This work both draws on and contributes to the study of the "anatomy of integers", which is a central topic in elementary/analytic number theory. 

Broader impacts include several expository papers, the textbook on algebraic number theory alluded to above, mentoring of talented high school students at the Ross/Asia summer program, and minicourses in the Dominican Republic training prospective number theory PhD students.
